cncf so I'll highlight a few key milestones in the journey so this was in
2020 January when cubet saw a large scale adoption in the China's Highway

2021 we had Seda and edish so Seda basically is a tool for uh improving or
enhancing these AI workloads by enabling the collaboration between the edge and the cloud so the idea is that we would
have a lightweight model at the edge and then there will be a model at the cloud
then there is Edge mesh so Edge mesh is a networking tool for communication of
uh communication between these Edge nodes and then in 2021 September we had the
first Cloud native vehicle that was based on cubet so Q here was being used
for uh over the top over thee upgrades at the software level uh then we had this uh first Cloud
native satellite so this was in 2021 December and this is where this uh cloud
and Edge uh This Cloud and Edge uh integrated solution was tested in space

project so a uh a small background about what H Computing is so basically hedge
Computing is bringing the workloads as close to the user or as close to the
edge as possible where the data is being generated or where the action uh action
is being taken so if you look at this uh diagram you'll see that we have this AIS
Which is closest to the user and it has the minimum latency and then there is aggregation
which would like uh collect the collect the traffic from multiple
accesses and then there is Metro which has the maximum latency which is like
the connection between the regional Edge and the cloud So based upon these uh
latencies we have these use cases like for exess we have near side edge and
City Edge or far Edge these two are have use cases like v2x like AR VR AI Etc so
v2x is like uh vehicle to everything it's a technology for vehicles to interact with its environment so that
they can perform things like uh autonomous driving or road safety Etc
and a lightweight model can perform AI inference at this near side edge or city Edge then for regional Edge typical use
cases would be uh CDN and uh arvr or or compute spec uh compute heavy tasks like
uh rendering video rendering video transcoding Etc and then for cloud we
have uh use cases like uh big data and uh AI training AI inference
Etc so where Q comes into play is Q is uh uh Q basically provides a consistent
experience of these uh applications and resources data services between the edge
and the cloud and uh the aim with Cube edges is to bring these Cloud native
Technologies to the edge is to enable Edge Computing so if we look at the data
centers or if we look at the cloud the services are very mature the
infrastructure is very mature but at the edge things are still developing and uh
that's why Q was created and that's why QB was made open source and donated to cncf so that we could bring in this uh
Community Driven development and this open source development to the project and uh we have had great response from

different organizations and a few student contributors also like

there's Cloud side edge and the devices so at the cloud you'll see Cloud Core

is requesting for data then mapper would fetch that data for that application

kubernetes services so it provides a more flexible
and unified way to manage all these iot devices if you look at the diagram
you'll see this mapper which would which is basically doing all this heavy

firstly we have these life cycle uh actions like creating a device updating
deleting Etc we can also perform health checks and then there is uh updating
device twin or reporting the device events so this is useful for monitoring
from the central cloud and then there are updates like uh OTA management and

Etc then the recent uh updates in this uh DMI have been we have added a new
device API and now mapper also supports uh data coming as a video streaming form
and then we have also upgraded the support for we have also added support for upgrading the
mapper talking about the edge architecture so in the recent updates we
have had this uh support for pre pulling this image on the edge so this basically
reduces the container startup time because images can be pulled at the
advanced in advance and then there is support for auto rescaling these Edge
modules so this is good for uh reliability because anytime we can choose to Auto rep Auto automatically
restart these Edge components and then there is uh there is uh support for more
uh device overrides basically this is for improving the flexibility so that these uh deployments can be
specific to the edge environment if you look at the edge mesh
this is a tool by cubage for communication between various uh Edge
nodes so in earlier versions with EDG mesh we used to have a centralized
server which would perform all these communication with where through which these communication would be passed on
but now we have uh come up with this server lless design so whenever there is communication between two Edge nodes
then we have these Edge mesh agents on each of these Edge nodes so whenever there's communication then these Edge
nodes or these Edge mesh agents will step in and perform the responsibility
of a server basically then another thing I wanted to talk about was this node
level data persistence actually I should have talked about this with Cubit so we also allow for node level data
persistence so so that even if the edge node would go offline or even if it is
not connected to the control plane then also it can work and it can recover even
if it's offline then there is support for layer 4 and layer 7 traffic management so
layer four is basically for basic data like TCP and UDP and then layer 7 is for
application Level data like uh HTTP https Etc then and another work in progress is
to enable sto for self-governance talking about the six
security so Cu uh Q has had its uh third party security audit by Eda Logics this
was in 2022 and uh Q became the first CN one of the first cncf projects to reach
the level three slsa certification and then for Source build and common areas we have level for
certification if you want to read more about these audit reports you can scan these QR codes also we were one of the
first projects to integrate with fussing so this enables it uh cubed to be much
more uh much less vulnerable and we can find out these potential uh security
loopholes through fuzzing talking about the AI part so for
this we have sedna so sedna basically is a tool for
improving or for enhancing these AI workloads by enabling a collaboration between the edge part and the cloud part
so what how this basically works is we would have a lightweight model at the edge which would perform this inference
and then we would also have a model at the cloud so if you look at this diagram
we we have this Global manager which would perform um task management and
coordination so that uh from the central level from the cloud level we can execute all these Ai workloads and then
it also performs uh model and data set management so this is so that the cloud
or we can have centralized control over the AI model and over the data and this
Cloud node will be talking to this Edge note through this bridge of local controller and if you look at both these
notes you'll see worker these worker performs the inference so all this uh
inference and training is performed by the worker and uh so because of this Edge
and Cloud uh collaboration we have the following uh training and inference
Frameworks so we have joint inference we have uh incremental learning Federated
learning and uh lifelong learning I'll talk about these individually but the idea is with joint inference we want to
have basically for joint inference we will have a lightweight or a shallow model at
the edge and we will have a another model deep model at the cloud and if
there is a request and it can be processed locally uh it can be uh processed by inferring the data locally
then it would be done for reducing the uh latency and if not then it'll go to the cloud then there is incremental
learning which basically is that the model keeps on learning with new data uh
being fed uh fed and then these being accumulated over the cloud and there is
Federated learning for data privacy and for security reasons and then there is
lifelong learning where we basically manage a knowledge Library talking about the oak ecosystem
so we are compatible with most of these popular Frameworks like popular AI
Frameworks like tensorflow P torch pedal Etc
so this is the sedna lifelong learning service if you look at the diagram
you'll see there is a knowledge Library so this is basically persistently storing all the data that is coming from
this Edge and this Edge will be performing these uh tasks like uh unseen
tasks will be uh processed at the edge and all the data will be going to the
and persistently be storing at the uh knowledge Library this is so that we can avoid the problem of catastrophic
forgetting and then uh basically this uh knowledge Library would perform all the
inference here then there is a seta Federated
learning service so idea basically here is that the isolated data at the edge
should not leave the edge this is mostly for uh security reasons or for
compliance reasons so what happens is at the edge we have a local training
algorithm uh which would perform the training at the edge and the raw data
will not be sent at the cloud only the model parameters will be updated at the cloud and uh Cloud will be running this
uh aggregation algorithm so with this one more thing I would want to talk about is multitask
detection so with Federated learning uh actually uh we have these unbalanced set
of unbalanced sample sets so for these uh for cloud we have large data set for
uh Cloud models but for Hedge for some Edge nodes we may have access to a large
data set and for some Ed we may not have that so for this we have multitask
detection basically what this does is it divides these non IID sample sets so IID
is basically nonindependent and identically distributed sample sets so
all these tasks that are similar will be grouped together and will be executed
together for firstly for better accuracy and then for for accuracy and this is also
important because it will help in uh reducing the resource
usage talking about the joint inference so with joint inference we
have a shallow model running at the edge and we have a deep model that is running in the cloud so what happens here is
that uh if a request is sent by the user then and the confidence level is met by
inference at the edge so the uh response will be returned or the action will be
taken at the edge itself it will not be connected to Cloud so this way we can
have lesser latency we can reduce the latency and if the confidence level is
not met it would be inferred in the cloud so this is how we can find uh this
is how we can find a fine balance between the latency and accuracy or
Precision so basically the AI developers would provide data to train these models
at the edge and the cloud and then business developers would deploy them to the
